entries.meaning: (Australia, obsolete) An itinerant worker, such as a swagman, who arrives at a farm too late in the day to do any work, but readily accepts food and lodging.
examples: What he saw was not usual in this part of Australia - a sundowner, a bush waif who tramps from north to south or from east to west, never working, cadging rations from the far-flung homesteads and having the ability of the camel to do without water, or find it.

entries.meaning: (Australia, obsolete) An itinerant worker, a swagman.
(nautical) A sea captain who shows harsh discipline by requiring all hands to be on board by sundown.
(medicine, colloquial) A patient, usually demented, who tends to become agitated in the evening.
examples: These patients may improve by day only to relapse at night (nocturnal delirium or sundowner's syndrome).

entries.meaning: (originally colonial slang, especially southern Africa) A cocktail consumed at sunset, or to signify the end of the day.
examples: The cocktail, the universal “sherry and bitters” and sundowner will have to be retained.

entries.meaning: A cocktail party held in the early evening.
examples: The Sundowner is basically a cocktail party with a buffet on a riverbank in the bush.

entries.meaning: A physician employed by the government who practises for private fees after his official hours.
Any worker who practises for private fees after official hours.
examples: These "sundowners" hold jobs in other — usually related — trades, and do their servicing nights and weekends.
